name: Freebie
description: Freebie is a casual game where you launch a ball against a paddle and hit a green surface. Be careful not to hit the red surfaces or you'll lose a life!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or better Processor: 1.2 Ghz Memory: 512 MB RAM Storage: 100 MB available space

The author wasn't joking when he said this game is casual. It's very simple, getting all the achievements might take as little as 10-15 minutes if you approach it methodically (figure out a flow and the ball travel delay). Does it have lasting appeal or replay value? That depends, so before you buy, maybe watch my gameplay available  here . It's technically solid, with no bugs observed in the short time that I've played it. I will not be returning to it, but I admit it has a certain addictive quality, particularly if you'd want to challenge yourself by playing as quickly as possible instead of 'figuring out' each shot. The bottom line is, I +1'd my 'Perfect Games' counter in 15 minutes and for half a euro. That's a good deal.

I bought this game because I had a coupon, so it cost around 10 cents. I started playing the game because of my 'completionist ideas' and thought it would be an easy 5 achievements. I was wrong-ish. The game was simple and fun at first, but then after 30 points are earned things get a bit challenging. The bar starts messing wtih your eyes and timing becomes a thing. But, there is a sweet spot, but only when the right sides of the sqaure are lit, then you will have to really angle it. It's idea is as simple as pong but a lot more fun. There are some fire tracks to listen to as you play. Overall, this game is just 'simple fun' with some old school machanics.
Simple game but I still enjoyed it. I finished the epilepsy mode with a score of 69 which makes me dizzy for a few minutes. Pretty casual and enjoying.

This game is actually pretty fun, but it feels like it is more suited for a mini-game compilation than as a stand alone. Basically the objective is to serve balls at a spinning stick, and cause it to hit the balls into green walls. Simple and fun, but not much to do aside from trying to climb the leader board.

Why exactly does this exist? Why is the developer trying to charge money for it? It's called Freebie...   Freebie is a game where you launch balls at a rotating blue paddle in an attempt to hit green walls and avoid red ones.    There's not a whole lot to say about this game, other than it's called  FREEBIE  and it costs $1. I got it in a giveaway by the group listed as the developer, so I'm going to assume the sole purpose of this game was to be given away by this 'Free Games Info'. But that just begs the question: Why the hell are they trying to charge $1 for it?   This is nothing more than (what should be) a free mobile app. Don't get it. There's nothing in this game that can't be seen in the videos/screenshots on this page.

Freebie should actually be a Free game... What you do in this game is you toss a ball at a spinning stick. Hoping to get it to the other color (or colour). And that's what you do for the whole game. Oh and you get three lives. But, if you really into puzzle games and wanting something cheap... Here's your game. If IIf I saved my money, I could've spent $5 at KFC, to buy chicken!

No no no no no no no. Even though I got it as a 'Freebie' in a giveaway, I can still say that this game is terrible. Controls are bad, sound is worse and the gameplay is so simple yet dumb a toddler could make something better.
